page.title: 17Transport problems/Guyzance.
page.content: The early settlers in this area would have used the River Coquet as their main communication route,travelling on the river itself or along it's banks. Today the area is covered by a network of narrow roads linking the farming communities with nearby villages. The absence of public transport means that almost every family is dependant on a motorcar,the nearest bus routes being up to three miles away.Members of the public can use the school bus during termtime,but the times are inconvenient and the service is rarely used. The London/Edinburgh railway passes through the area and two stations,Acklington and Alnmouth,are easily accessible by car. This has led to several cottages being bought by daily commuters to Newcastle upon Tyne.
